Position:

The position property controls the type of positioning used by an element within its parent elements. The effect of the position attribute depends on a lot of factors, for example the value of position property of parent elements.

In this tutorial, we are going to look at how positioning will change the relationship between parent and child elements.

Parent

A parent element is an element that contains other elements.

Child

All elements that are contained within that parent are called "child" elements.

properties:

position: static;

Default. Object has no special positioning; it follows the layout rules of HTML. Values of top, bottom, left and right have no impact.

position: absolute;

Object is positioned relative to parent element's position—or to the body object if its parent element is not positioned—using the top and left properties.

position: relative;

Object is positioned according to the normal flow, and then offset by the top and left properties.

position: fixed;

Object is positioned relative to the viewport containing the content. Object stays in the viewport when scrolling. Usually used for navigation on mobile devices. Limited support.

Examples

parent: static
child: static

position: static; Default. Object has no special positioning; it follows the layout rules of HTML. Values of top, bottom, left and right have no impact.

parent: static
child: absolute

position: absolute; Object is positioned relative to parent element's position—or to the body object if its parent element is not positioned—using the top and left properties.
